ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

comments: Kind of Brent Frey and Elaine? Are they official TAs?
Brent Frey and Elaine Hopper
Elaine Hooper, Brent Frey
Elaine Hooper and Brent Frey
Elaine Hooper, Brent Frey
Eileen

Elaine and Brent

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This class was way better than doing a project course by myself. Accountability to my peers and Mark helped me get my stuff in on time, and I got much better at explaining my hypotheses via repeatedly having to clarify them to our group. I really enjoyed it and think every disciplinary area in which we have MEScs should have such a class. It's like a lab group for a doctoral degree candidate - you just benefit so much from having peers to hear you out and sound ideas off of.

This class is super useful if you are interested in the scientific publication process, or learning how to look at and present a scientific study. It would not be useful for someone with a strictly management focus.

This is a very hands-on course that provides students with useful analytical skills to review scientific literature in silviculture and provides a step by step approach to writing scientific papers. Students undertake scientific studies in the field to investigate silvicultural issues and assisted through hypotheses formulation, data capture and analyses and presentation of report.
Top of the notch class. Really what I came to look for at Yale.

Question 10 - this course is so helpful and informative for any masters student working to develop their research project into something you can clearly express both in a journal article and in a project presentation.

Pizza and beer. Just kidding. Literally, everything. Discussion of papers at the beginning was great - really set the tone. I would have liked a third paper to review perhaps - one more on the line between accept/reject. I think we could have done one fewer round of presentations (or made it optional), and having us hand in our entered data before Tgiving would have helped us each make sure it was actually entered. Not for review by Mark, so much as just so we actually made sure to prioritize it. It's quite a bit of hand-holding, but whatever -this class works, and that's what matters. I love that you're requiring us to hand in our drafts and get comments (even if I'm behind on getting mine in).
The many draft deadlines.
The opportunity it presents for independent work and the system of peer-reviewing that enriches the whole exercise

Getting a jump start on processing all my data and getting my presentations and thoughts put together. Mark is great and very helpful as are the other students in class. We are all very invested in the success of these projects and so it is great to work together.

The very interactive process of writing your own paper while constantly getting feedback from your professor, TAs and peersTHis class is priceless, really helped me a lot developing my writing, reading, analyzing and synthesizing skills
Having deadlines to keep me on track for progressing with my research.

The encouragement to make progress on the introduction, methods and preliminary results of my research project. The ability to not only write and get feedback on written work, but also practice articulating your project in a presentation form in front of peers, professors, and doctoral students. Holding composure and clearly responding to difficult questions is very useful building confidence and presentation skills.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: A little bit more professorial direction (more teaching and less redundant presenting) between the second and third round of presentations would be an asset. More statistical help (perhaps require a meeting with TAs well-versed in at least multivariate stats?) would be a huge asset as well.

This year's class was sizable and maybe it should be smaller given the configuration of the course. it's a trade off because you loose peers with different points of view while you gain more reviewing time from others for your paper

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Everything I needed, I got. I met or chatted with Mark and am meeting with Elaine to work on stats this week. In fact, I'm supposed to be finishing my data entry right now. Whoops.
Very good. Both TAs and Mark are very willing to meet to talk about projects.
Both instructor and TAs were very available and eager to assist through appointments and walk ins.
The three of them always available and helpfulI would contact the professor directly for advice
Eileen was very responsive and helpful in working on the stats of my project.
I contacted one of the TAs for advice out of class. The in class help of the students and professor were very valuable. The professor gave great comments on written assignments.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I am an MESc student - what could possibly be a better fit? By having an actual class structure it ensured we put the hours in each week, and kept our summer experiences and the resultant data in the foreground. I only wish this course met the semester before students went and the semester after, since that (I think) is when it's most needed. The students here really need labgroups or some kind of within-discipline peer support network. This did that job.
It provides the tools and capacity to publish scientific work of high quality for journals and thus contribute towards silvicultural knowledge
As an MESc this leads to a successful published paper. In this way it is a really important course in my overall program.
Given my science degree, this class is vital to my interests and also to anyone doing forest science or even environmental sciences.
As stated before, it was a great way to increase the quality and productivity of my thesis project.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am an MESc student with a publication to write! (er, being written...right now...)
I wanted to be able to construct a manuscript for publication.
To be able to publish scientific papers and improve my analytical skills in evaluating findings of scientific work

to get my summer research analyzed and published. because i wanted mark's input and needed the peer pressure to get motivated. i have a hard time doing science in a vacuum and really appreciate that my peers and i can talk about our work as we go through it. it makes this degree much less isolating
Because my main interest is silviculture and this class of advanced silciculture is exactly what i was seeking
To make steady progress on my master's project
To keep moving forward with my research with the help of constructive input from my peers and advisor.
To get the detailed support and comraderie of "lab group" as a master's student working on a scientific field research project.

Yes
Exceeded my expectation. This wasthe most important or second most important course I took this semester.
yes
very much indeed
Yes

Yes

yes

Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Even though there were no group assignments, the system of peer-reviewing created an opportunity for joint learning, sharing views and commenting on work undertaken by colleagues. And the feedback from colleagues, TAs and instructor were great

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: This is the best thing youcould do for yourself coming back from the field, and if you have a poor advisor (I used to last year but changed to someone who is much better), it will ground you and give you a scientific community in which to test your ideas and talk it out. You're crazy not to take this course if you are a forest-studying MESc or MFS.
Make sure you stay on top of assignments and your data, so not let things build up until the end of the semester.

This is a very intense course that draws on many other fields of study. One needs to understand silviculture thoroughly and be able to apply that knowledge to solving problems. A good knowledge of statistical analysis is required. A great learning experience.
keep up the good work. get started early. every step takes way longer than you think it will.
Take the class, you won't regret it.It's a phD level class perfectly suitable for any environmental science student, although forest science people fit perfectly
If you do better working under deadlines and with the help of your peers, this is the class for you. I really valued it.

Take the course in the first place. The only drawback I found was that I almost did not take the course because I had no idea it was offerend and what the course was about based on the title. Only by word of mouth did I discover how valuable a course this would be.
